ygData.subject: "Survive and Reproduce" as an Objective
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, I wanted to branch my response to you to a new thread because I want to focus on the idea that survive and reproduce is an objective.  This is not

Subject: "Survive and Reproduce" as an Objective
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=9m9yttPXh3a_3Wsg0_V1knPK8O4IRC1JbJ3OT81cBWLR1UxaCqGu

Colin, I wanted to branch my response to you to a new thread because I wa=
nt to focus on the idea that "survive and reproduce" is an objective.  This=
 is not really an argument with anything you said, but mainly a commentary =
on the meaning of "objective" that I think draws a useful distinction.

I d=
on't deny that the word "objective" in a dictionary or common-use sense can=
 be used to cover "survive and reproduce."  However, I think the idea that =
survive-and-reproduce is an objective causes a lot of confusion for the fie=
ld of evolutionary computation and therefore should be dropped.  The proble=
m is that "objective" in evolutionary computation has come to mean "what we=
 want to evolve," which is a lot different from survive-and-reproduce.  Thu=
s these are really two different types of things, and therefore the word "o=
bjecitve" does us a disservice by conflating them as a single type of probl=
em.

For example, consider that the very first organism(s) on Earth in the =
very first generation already could survive and reproduce.  Yet since when =
have we run an evolutionary algorithm whose "objective" is already achieved=
 in the very first generation (unless it's something very trivial)?  In oth=
er words, it is part of the "algorithm" of nature that survive-and-reproduc=
e is achieved from the start, which is a strange idea for a traditional EC =
objective.

Then, from that point, this so-called "objective" is simply ach=
ieved and re-achieved over and over again.  This dynamic is completely cont=
rary to the kind of objective in an EA, which you would stop as soon as the=
 objective is achieved, not leave running. Yet in nature all the greatness =
is from leaving it running after the "objective" is already achieved.

So I=
 think survive-and-reproduce isn't what we mean by an objective in EC.  We =
mean things that haven't been achieved that we want the algorithm to achiev=
e in the future.  

This distinction is important because it shows why the =
EA-style of objective is potentially handicapped.  After all, if you look a=
gain at nature, what we marvel at is what it evolved, not the survival and =
reproduction itself.  We marvel at brains and wings and photosynthesis.  Th=
ese artifacts are much closer to what EC means by an "objective" than survi=
ve-and-reproduce.  Yet they were *not* the objective; they are orthogonal d=
iscoveries on the road to nowhere in particular.  And that is why I think i=
n spirit, in the spirit of EC at least, nature has no EC-style objective.  =
All its power is from the fact that it discovers things that it is not rewa=
rded explicitly to produce.  In that sense, for me, saying that nature has =
no objective captures more clearly how starkly different it is from the way=
 we traditionally run our algorithms and the way we think about search toda=
y.

Perhaps it can be said more succinctly:  For EC, an objective is someth=
ing for which the algorithm is explicitly rewarded for producing.  In this =
sense, the kinds of things nature produced are not objectives.  Thus nature=
 is a non-objective search.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Gree=
n <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> On 2 April 2011 00:09, Ken <kstanley@...> w=
rote:
> > Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our new paper to appe=
ar at GECCO, "On the
> > Deleterious Effects of A Priori Objectives on Evol=
ution and Representation." You can get it
> > here:
> >
> > http://eplex.cs=
.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco11.pdf
> 
> Thanks, I definitely think this is=
 worthy research avenue. I have a
> few thoughts on the subject that I'd li=
ke to express, some more well
> formed than others :)
> 
> Firstly, there i=
s of course an objective driving evolution in the
> natural world albeit a =
very broad one, that is, being able to survive
> and for long enough to rep=
roduce (and anything else you can do towards
> increasing the chances that =
your offspring will survive and
> reproduce). It just so happens that the n=
atural world has an incredily
> complex structure that allows for many diff=
erent ways (niches) of
> eking out a living with a wide range of strategies=
 from the relatively
> simple (e.g. single celled algae floating in the sea=
) to the more
> complex (e.g. writing software for a living). It also just =
so happens
> that the sub-environments and niches have significant overlap =
in terms
> of the strategies that work in one can sort of work in many othe=
rs. As
> such there are many routes for evolution to take from simple to
> =
complex life, not just a series of stepping stones but complex
> overlappin=
g and criss-crossing paths.
> 
> Evolution discovered eyesight independentl=
y multiple times over
> because it was a recurring 'problem' in all of thes=
e evolutionary
> niches and one for which a solution was 'nearby' in the en=
coding space
> of biological genetics, the same is true for other phenomeno=
n (flight
> has been discovered independently, e.g. insects, birds, bats). =
This
> kind of shows that the biological encoding space is perhaps less
> s=
usceptible to getting stuck than NEAT (but it does have a lot more
> space-=
time to play with, so perhaps not that much better)
> 
> So for me the main=
 lesson from nature is that if you wish to evolve
> agents with complex str=
ategies then you probably need to a complex
> environment (fitness space) t=
hat provides a wide range of overlapping
> niches and stepping stones all t=
he way from the simple through to the
> complex. So from this perspective t=
he miracle of life on earth is due
> 50% to the mirace of evolution and 50%=
 due to the miracle of the
> structure of the natural world. Evolution did =
need large numbers to
> work with (e.g. vast oceans of microscopic single c=
elled creatures and
> 3.5 billion years) to make all the leaps required to =
get where it is,
> but each of those leaps was possible because of the over=
lapping nature
> of the available niches.
> 
> It's perhaps this latter 50%=
 of the miracle that is generally
> overlooked in evolutionary computing ci=
rcles, we've tended to see the
> process of evolution as the solution but h=
ave overlooked the
> absolutely pivotal role of deep complexity in the fitn=
ess space.
> Without that complexity probably the best you can do is to mak=
e one of
> those small leaps - essentially searching a local space.
> 
> Th=
e problem with objective based search then, as I see it, is that the
> obje=
ctives we have tended to focus on are too focused and rigid.
> 
> 
> Colin
=
>
